comment.author: 7892196@N02
comment._content: Looks like it was taken from the Silos and the approaches look clean and uncluttered which suggests a date c1921 when the silo opened.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: This is White Bay power station.   Not Balmain Power Station.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The building to the left of the power station is the White Bay Hotel,  quite recently demolished.  The street going up the hill behind it is Hornsey Street.     Victoria Road, then called Weston Road,  runs up the hill but I can't actually see it anywhere in the photo.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I think the two buildings to the right of the last chimney,  is the former catholic church at the top of Gordon Street.  The large staggered building on the skyline was a cinema, which was later a wedding reception venue,  on the corner of red lion street.    You can also see St Thomas' anglican church.     The two other visible towers are a mystery,  I don't know what they are.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Thanks! Yes it looks like this is White Bay Power Station. www.dictionaryofsydney.org/image/20926. Balmain powerstation was an entirely different building on land now occupied by the Balmain Shores apartment development near Iron Cove bridge. www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/balmain_power_station?zo...

comment.author: 111716589@N03
comment._content: Hi, I have incorporated the photo into my webpage about the White Bay Power Station. The photo could be circa 1933, when NEW BOILERS were installed. More at City Energy: White Bay Power Station
